DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the product tissue donor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A thing produced by or resulting from a process. EXAMPLE(S): drug, device. The FDA list of regulated products: animal and human drugs; therapeutic biologics; allergenics; cell, tissue and gene therapy products; blood components; blood derivative products; devices; and animal (pets and livestock) and human food/feed (medicated and un-medicated); cosmetics; pet treats; and dietary supplements._ In medicine, a person who gives blood, cells, tissue, or an organ for use in another person, such as in a blood transfusion or an organ transplant.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.

Concepts.definition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.

Property.preferredDefinition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

Concepts.definition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Body tissue, region, surface, cavity, fluid, organ, or collection of organs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Marrow Donor Program Unrelated Donor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-profit organization based in Minneapolis, MN, that facilitates hematopoietic cell transplants for patients by connecting patients, doctors, donors and researchers to the resources they need.: Unrelated; not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

Concepts.definition: A non-profit organization based in Minneapolis, MN, that facilitates hematopoietic cell transplants and cellular therapies for patients by connecting patients, doctors, donors and researchers to the resources they need.
Not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.
Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: MHC Class I Protein MHC Class II Protein Identical Sibling

ValueMeaning.preferredName: MHC Class I Protein MHC Class II Protein Identical Sibling
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Found on virtually every cell, MHC (Major Histocompatibility, HLA) Class-I (Antigens) Proteins consist of noncovalently bound polymorphic 44-kDa MHC membrane glycoprotein and nonpolymorphic 12-kDa b2-microglobulin. The HLA antigens are encoded by closely linked multiallelic genes of the HLA (MHC) complex, a region containing several genetic loci (HLA-A, -B, -C, -DP, -DQ, -DR, -MB, -MT, and -Te).: MHC Class-II Proteins are non-covalently linked polymorphic alpha/beta transmembrane glycoproteins. The immunological function of MHC Class-II proteins is to bind and present antigenic peptides on the surfaces of cells for recognition by the antigen-specific T cell receptors of lymphocytes. These proteins plays an important role in the mediation of immune response.: Exactly alike; incapable of being perceived as different; being the exact same one; coinciding exactly when superimposed; having properties with uniform values along all axes.: Sibling; a person's brother or sister.

Concepts.definition: Found on virtually every cell, MHC (Major Histocompatibility, HLA) Class-I (Antigens) Proteins consist of noncovalently bound polymorphic 44-kDa MHC membrane glycoprotein and nonpolymorphic 12-kDa b2-microglobulin. The HLA antigens are encoded by closely linked multiallelic genes of the HLA (MHC) complex, a region containing several genetic loci (HLA-A, -B, -C, -DP, -DQ, -DR, -MB, -MT, and -Te).

MHC Class-II Proteins are non-covalently linked polymorphic alpha/beta transmembrane glycoproteins. The immunological function of MHC Class-II proteins is to bind and present antigenic peptides on the surfaces of cells for recognition by the antigen-specific T cell receptors of lymphocytes. These proteins plays an important role in the mediation of immune response.
Exactly alike; incapable of being perceived as different; being the exact same one; coinciding exactly when superimposed; having properties with uniform values along all axes.
A person's brother or sister.

The HLA antigens are encoded by closely linked multiallelic genes of the HLA (MHC) complex, a region containing several genetic loci (HLA-A, -B, -C, -DP, -DQ, -DR, -MB, -MT, and -Te).: MHC Class-II Proteins are non-covalently linked polymorphic alpha/beta transmembrane glycoproteins. The immunological function of MHC Class-II proteins is to bind and present antigenic peptides on the surfaces of cells for recognition by the antigen-specific T cell receptors of lymphocytes. These proteins plays an important role in the mediation of immune response.: Not otherwise specified.: Relative; a person related by blood or marriage.

Concepts.definition: Found on virtually every cell, MHC (Major Histocompatibility, HLA) Class-I (Antigens) Proteins consist of noncovalently bound polymorphic 44-kDa MHC membrane glycoprotein and nonpolymorphic 12-kDa b2-microglobulin. The HLA antigens are encoded by closely linked multiallelic genes of the HLA (MHC) complex, a region containing several genetic loci (HLA-A, -B, -C, -DP, -DQ, -DR, -MB, -MT, and -Te).

MHC Class-II Proteins are non-covalently linked polymorphic alpha/beta transmembrane glycoproteins. The immunological function of MHC Class-II proteins is to bind and present antigenic peptides on the surfaces of cells for recognition by the antigen-specific T cell receptors of lymphocytes. These proteins plays an important role in the mediation of immune response.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
A person related by blood or marriage.

These proteins plays an important role in the mediation of immune response.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::8/8: The state when a recipient and their donor have the same alleles for tissue markers. A full match includes HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1. HLA match typing may also include alleles in the HLA-DQ serogroup.: Not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.

The state when a recipient and their donor have the same alleles for tissue markers. A full match includes HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1. HLA match typing may also include alleles in the HLA-DQ serogroup.
Not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: 6/6 HLA-A Gene HLA-B Gene HLA-DRB1 Gene Match Relationship

ValueMeaning.preferredName: 6/6 HLA-A Gene HLA-B Gene HLA-DRB1 Gene Match Relationship
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::6/6: This gene is involved in immune responses and histocompatibility processes.: This gene plays a role in both immune responses and histocompatibility processes.: The class of genes that encode proteins of the major histocompatibility complex, class II, DR beta; HLA type II genes.: An exact duplicate; coinciding in characteristics; similar or consistent.: A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
This gene is involved in immune responses and histocompatibility processes.
This gene plays a role in both immune responses and histocompatibility processes.
This gene is involved in immunoregulation and antigen presentation. The gene has several hundred alleles and polymorphism typing is routinely performed for bone marrow and kidney transplantation.
An exact duplicate; coinciding in characteristics; similar or consistent.
A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A donor who has only one haplotype in common with the recipient.

Concepts.definition: A donor who has only one haplotype in common with the recipient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A donor who is not related to the transplant recipient, and who is not a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) tissue type match at one or more of the following loci: HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1.

Concepts.definition: A donor who is not related to the transplant recipient, and who is not a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) tissue type match at one or more of the following loci: HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A donor who is not related to the transplant recipient, but who is a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) tissue type match.

Concepts.definition: A donor who is not related to the transplant recipient, but who is a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) tissue type match.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of hematopoietic progenitor cells for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for a hematopoietic disorder.

Concepts.definition: Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of hematopoietic progenitor cells for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for a hematopoietic disorder.
